text:
Good afternoon, and welcome
to our fourth session, Macroeconomics of
a Novel Crisis,

featuring Professor Carmen
Reinhart of the Harvard Kennedy School. Our moderator is HBS
professor Laura Alfaro.

If you have reactions
to the conversations, you're welcome to
put them on chat.

Please know that a
recording of the session will be made available to
a broader public audience.

your name and voice will
be part of that recording. Handing it over to you, Laura.

Hi, Willy. Thank you. So now we go into
economics, so what

started as a health shock,
a virus, as we all know, became an economic
problem, an economic crisis

now a worldwide crisis. The IMF has just recently
put out some numbers.

They now expect this to be
worse than the Great Depression, and many analysts believe
these are estimates

on the optimistic side. So we're going to try to discuss
the economic consequences.

And for these, I have
the great pleasure to have and introduce
Carmen Reinhart.

So Carmen is the Minos
A. Zombanakis Professor of International Finance Systems
at the Harvard Kennedy School.

She was also visiting the
finance unit last term. Carmen was senior policy advisor
and deputy director at IMF.

She was also a member
of the economic advisors to the Congressional
Budget Office.

She was also chief
economist at Bear Stearns in the '80s, and so first hand
the great default of the '80s

and the lost decade
in emerging markets. She is also a member of
the Federal Reserve Bank

advisory board. She's one of the most
cited economists worldwide.

She had received many awards,
the Adam Smith Award recently, the King Juan Carlos prize.

She's listed as Bloomberg most
influential people in finance,

foreign policy global thinkers. And the reason why Carmen's
work is so influential

is because she has
defined the way we understand financial crisis
in industrialized countries,

in emerging markets. Her work is detailed,
exhaustive, comprehensive

across time, across countries. And again, let's emphasize, this
has become a worldwide crisis.

Her best selling book, which
of course I have in my office,

This Time is Different-- Eight Centuries of
Financial Folly. It's encyclopedic in a good
way, perhaps also prophetic,

has been translated in 20
languages, has won many prizes.

Every news outlet you read
right now has a piece by Carmen.

Every country is trying
to get her views. So Carmen, thank you very much
to make time to talk to us.

Can you hear me? Yes. OK, thank you for
inviting me and thank you for that wonderful introduction.

Thank you. No, as I said, it's an honor. We have a lot of
things to cover.

But let me start
with our recent piece you wrote for Project Syndicate,
"This Time is Truly Different."

Can you give us a sense of
how this crisis is evolving,

comparative sense, and then in
economic and financial terms?

So the first thing
I'd like to mention is pandemics, unfortunately,
are not new in history.

We've had a lot of pandemics
through the course of history. To start with one
that is referenced

very often in the current
press is the 1918 to 1920

Spanish influenza. And what motivated
me also to say this time is truly different
or truly is different

is if you look at
starting with the US,

if you look at the
1918 pandemic, which holds the record in
terms of mortality,

it actually offers us very
little guidelines on what to expect on the
economic front this time

around, because the year
1918 when the pandemic deaths

peaked in the United States, the
US was involved in World War I,

and real GDP, that year,
despite all the casualties, despite the pandemic, grew 9%,
and business failures actually

were new. And so we really can't
use that as our benchmark.

I think a more
relevant benchmark to compare what we're
going through right now

is the global crisis of
the 1930s, known otherwise

as the Depression. The reasons I say that are
manifold, but let me just

highlight a few of them. Number one, if you go back to
the 2008-2009 crisis, which

more people, obviously,
have fresh in their mind, it was called
global, and it indeed

affected the global economy
in late 2008, early 2009,

but it really was
a banking crisis in 11 advanced economies.

The US and Europe were really
the heart of that crisis. The emerging markets,
at that time,

were badly hit in the end
of 2008, beginning of 2009, but proceeded to have a very
robust V-shaped recovery,

and this was led by China
and high commodity prices. So you go back to
the 1980s, and that

was an emerging market crisis,
not an advanced economy crisis. You go to the 1930s, and it
is global, affecting both

advanced and emerging and
developing countries in tandem.

So that, to me, is the
frame of reference. Other similarities to
the 1930s, which were not

present in the global
financial crisis of 2008-2009,

I've already alluded to. The environment
that we're facing

is one of very depressed
commodity prices up until--

notwithstanding,
and we will see what OPEC really delivers
on that score.

But we've had, in addition,
as if the coronavirus wasn't

enough, we've had
the Saudi-Russian oil war, which has led to plummeting
oil prices, depressed commodity

prices. This obviously impacts a huge
number of commodity producers

globally. It also impacts big time the US. We have our emerging
market within the US

in the context of the energy
industry, the oil industry.

So number one
parallel, it's global, like the '30s, unlike the global
financial crisis of 2008-2009.

It is accompanied by
depressed commodity prices. That was true during the 1930s.

Turning now to another
parallel with the 1930s, the WTO a few days ago
came out with a forecast

for trade growth for 2020
that ranges from what

is already a depressing
decline, potentially, of 13%,

to what is a completely out
of the box decline of possibly

minus 32% in global trade. The last time we
had a global trade

implosion of that magnitude
was, again, in the 1930s.

This is multiple
standard deviations

in terms of annual
changes to global trade. So depressed commodity
prices, even more depressed

global trade, synchronicity
of the economic downturn,

and last, but certainly
not least, volatility, financial market volatility.

Financial markets
have been nothing less than a roller coaster. This is not a seat of the
pants statements, if you will.

In ongoing work that I have on
the history of capital flows with Vincent Reinhart
and Christoph Trebesch,

we constructed a VIX,
a monthly volatility

index for the US
stock market that goes back to 1885, monthly.

And I would observe
that there are two observations in the upper
1% of the VIX in the post World

War II era. That's October '87 and
March of this year.

The remaining observations
of such excessive volatility

in financial markets go back
to 1929, 1931, '32, '33.

So the disarray, if you will,
in global capital markets

is also much more
akin to the '30s than to any other episode
that I am aware of.

Thank you, Carmen. And again, this
is unprecedented,

and the fact that it's global
poses additional challenges.

Perhaps, we've seen
policymakers act, but again,

are they fighting
the last crisis, or do you see policies
in the right direction?

Some lessons from
your work, and again, we've seen policies
fiscal, monetary,

employment insurance, a
lot done in rich countries,

but what is your view of is this
heading in the right direction, do we need to do more?

Well, let me separate the
policy response into two parts.

The first part is unique,
really unique to this crisis.

The IMF just put out its
world economic outlook in the context of the
IMF annual meetings

and has called this
episode the Great Lockdown. So the fact that we have
had synchronous, or near

synchronous, economic
lockdowns of this magnitude

is a policy response to contain
the pandemic that we really haven't seen before.

And of course, the
understanding that this is in the context
of saving lives

and in containing
the pandemic, but it has had a massive negative
impact on activity

at every front, because-- and let's just very
briefly highlight how it--

obviously, any
country that depends on tourism or the service
industry associated

with human interaction of almost
any form is in standstill.

Countries that rely
on manufacturing are seeing supply
chains just erupted.

Countries that rely
on commodity exports are finding that because of
the crash in global demand,

commodity prices are
extremely depressed. So no one really escapes it.

And in terms of the
policy response, the second part of it, not the
one associated with containment

of the epidemic, the stimulus. So where does that
factor in as a response?

I have not seen
stimulus packages like what we are seeing
outside of major wars.

So this is, in terms
of the sheer scale

as a percent of
GDP, the magnitude,

that's the first thing, the
magnitude of the response is on a scale that you
really haven't seen increases

in government
spending and deficits like what we're going to record
in a large swath of countries

in peacetime. That's on scale. So direction now in terms of
mix and monetary policy, that's

what I'll turn to next. This crisis, the IMF is
calling it the Great Lockdown.

I would call it
the Great Implosion because one feature that's
very unique to this crisis,

and this bears importantly on
the policy response question, Laura, that you asked me.

Is it suddenness? If you look at US
unemployment claims,

it took us in the global
financial crisis 29 weeks

to get to where we've
gotten in three weeks. If you look at capital
flows to emerging markets,

I just did that using the
IIF data on weekly flows.

During the global financial
crisis of 2008-2009, the implosion in those
flows that we've seen

took about a year to
materialize to unfold. We've seen it in five weeks.

So what this highlights in
terms of the policy response is that the policy response
has to be immediate.

It has to be front loaded. And in that regard, I think the
US policy response certainly

scores highly in that
unlike more, if you will,

conventional fiscal
stimulus, such as investment

programs, more gradual
creation of jobs

and so on in the public
sector and the like, that won't cut it when you
have a decline this abrupt

in people's incomes. So as you know, phase one
of the US policy response

was largely-- it was smaller in
scale, and it was targeted towards
providing support

to the medical issue at large,
dealing with the pandemic.

The second wave was
also importantly

addressing the fact that
people are suddenly, as I mentioned, as I alluded
to, the spike, the massive spike

in jobless claims and
unemployment dealing with potential cash shortages
for those households

that have little
by way of saving to rely on during this
very difficult time.

So on the front loaded,
fast acting front,
I think it's very appropriate.

Let me turn to the
other-- the leg

three, if you will,
of the stimulus, which provides
basically the resources,

and now I'm coming to monetary
policy for the Federal Reserve to be able to finance the
segments of the economy that

are particularly hard
hit, which is almost

every sector in varying degrees,
by the economic implosion.

The initial response
of the Fed-- I was listening as Chairman
Jay Powell was speaking.

Say, OK, we're cutting
interest rates to zero. OK, that's great, but
that's not what we need. I mean, yes, lower interest
rates are, of course,

part of the story. But this is now a crisis. I alluded to already to the
severity of the turbulence

in financial markets
and the volatility where large chunks
of the economy

have been left without
access to credit,

and therefore, the
appropriate policy response

is beyond your conventional
interest rate response

and certainly beyond-- I mean, QE, as we knew
it back in 2008-2009

and thereafter was
unconventional then. It's pretty conventional now.

So the new element, if you
will, of unconventional policies

that we're seeing
to support activity is the establishment of
a multitude of facilities

that try to reach
out to segments like the municipal
market, segments

where banks that had a
very healthy loan portfolio

before COVID that,
all of a sudden, find themselves with a fresh
batch of non-performing loans

because their small business
loans are in the service

sectors that are in standstill. So the creation of
new facilities that

tries to move away from
just providing liquidity

to the treasury market
and to more broadly even

some of the AAA or
highly rated corporates, it's very important in this,
because the real problems are

not as much in that segment,
in that high quality

segment of the markets,
but we're seeing them, and we're seeing
this in the vast gap

in yields, the vast
gap in performance

between the lower grade paper
and the high grade corporate.

So where does that leave us? Is that sufficient? Well, I'd like to
turn for a moment

to the international
implications of that. The Fed is really the global
lender of last resort,

more or less. Formally, that's not
its role, but in the end the dollar is the
dominant currency.

We've seen dollar shortages
emerge throughout the globe. Where does that leave the
international dimension?

Well, the Fed,
yes, has swap lines with a handful of central banks.

But that's not particularly
helpful for most

of the countries. And what this has
created, I think,

is a bigger rift between
emerging market debt

and other high yield
debt that is not covered by these new facilities
that the Fed is supporting,

and the more speculative
grade assets.

This has very
important implications because it means more
corporate defaults, and it also means more
likely sovereign defaults
at the international level.

I think notwithstanding
what I've said about the scale of
the stimulus, the speed

of the stimulus, and
the Fed's efforts

to make it more inclusive, I
still think at the end, Laura,

this will not avoid a
big wave of defaults

on the corporate side in the
more speculative segments,

and I am very much afraid
at the international level

for many sovereigns whose credit
ratings are being slashed. Let me just add one element
that's particularly important

when it comes to talking about
countries that don't have the resources that the US
or other advanced economies,

wealthy economies. These countries are
seeing the lockdowns, but really don't
have the firepower

to do the fiscal stimulus that
is necessary to counteract those effects.

They certainly also
don't have the capacity for their central banks to
inject liquidity credit support

to the distressed sector. So I am very concerned
about a good chunk

of the global economy
that's in that situation. And staying on your
question, and I'll

conclude with this on the policy
response, one of the things that Ken Rogoff and I
have been writing about,

we did a piece for the
Wall Street Journal, we did another one, is trying
to get the IMF, World Bank,

the official lenders,
the G20 to orchestrate

a debt standstill for
developing and emerging markets.

And this goes beyond
the proposed standstill on official lending repayment.

It would incorporate
the private sector debt, and it would also
encompass more countries

than what the IMF World
Bank proposal has so far,

which is more limited to the
IDA countries, the poorest countries. I think the need is
much broader than just

in the poorest countries. I think it cuts a much broader
swath across emerging markets

as well. Let me stop there on that. I do appreciate bringing
it to lower and even middle

income countries. Even in Costa
Rica, where I think we have done great in
terms of the health part,

I am worried, as
you said, that we don't have the fiscal
capacity to do what it takes

because it is very abrupt. I think every country
seen destruction

of jobs, economic activity
at a level, as you mentioned, that we just have not witnessed.

And I'm sure there's going
to be more questions. And if not, I'll follow up
in the question section. But let's assume,
trying to be optimistic,

because after all,
we economists don't tend to have that side of us. But let's assume that in
one and a half, two years,

there is a vaccine. How do you see the
global economy emerging?

There was an early period
people described this as a V-shaped recovery. I just don't see this
V-shaped recovery.

Again, it might be
my lack of optimism. But are we heading into
an L shape, a lost decade?

What are the implications? Well, I share very
much your concern.

I wrote off a V-shaped
recovery pretty early on.

And the reason for that
is not, being, I think,

overly pessimistic
or overly cautious. I think the reason
for that is if you

look at the economic downturn,
it has been very synchronous,

but the spread of the
disease is not synchronous. It first hit China,
then hit Europe.

It's hitting the US. It really isn't projected
to hit many emerging markets

until later this year,
and so as long as you have the pandemic evolving
in part of the globe,

the idea that global supply
chains that have been disrupted can be normalized quickly,
or that people will resume

a normal, or anything resembling
a normal travel schedule and help the tourist industries
and the service industries that

are connected to that,
which is in many-- it affects many countries,
advanced and emerging.

So I think-- I'm not as negative as an L, OK? But there are certainly
very long U's, U's

with a very flat bottom. And I think we're in
one of those periods,
because the damage being done--

I alluded to the issue
of increasing defaults

at the corporate
and sovereign level, the issue of severe downgrades,
even if you don't quite
get to a default event.

And those are very
difficult hurdles

to overcome for many countries. And in the context of
the global economy,

there is another factor that
is worrying me considerably,

and it is connected to
the U-shaped pattern,

as opposed to a more-- and this, by the way, even
if the US and Europe come out

of this quicker, quicker, I
think, is going to be relative.

And let me say that I think the
whole concept of the paralysis

that we're seeing also will
lead to another related type of crisis, which
historically, often follows
on the heels of pandemics. And that is a food crisis.

And food crises are very
regressive, they have--

it's a breakdown of
distribution system. It's lack of labor in
the agricultural sector

and other kinds of dislocations
that are happening already. I think that also will
prolong the recovery.

Another factor, if all of
this is not sufficient,

Robert Shiller, in his work on
the aftermath of the Depression

of the '30s, highlighted
how risk aversion persisted for a while following
the height of the crisis.

Translate that to
economic activity. What does that mean? Are firms going to be
investing aggressively?

Are they going to be very quick
to rehire when uncertainty

is as significant as it is
likely to remain for some time

as long as the pandemic
isn't fully under control? So I'm highlighting.

These are not all the issues. I could go on. But these are some of
the key elements why

I think that a more protracted
recovery process is far more

likely. And let me-- again,
I don't want to be

overly pessimistic about this. I've highlighted so
far corporate defaults.

I've highlighted
sovereign defaults at the developing and
emerging market country level,

but I really don't
know what's going to happen in Europe in
the context of Italy

and in the context of Spain. If you recall, the 2008-2009
global financial crisis

was first and foremost
a banking crisis is associated with the housing
bubbles in various countries.

But that morphed into a debt
crisis in periphery Europe: it hit Portugal,
it hit Greece, it

hit Ireland particularly hard. It also hit Italy and Spain. But the three most
affected at that time

were Ireland,
Greece, and Portugal. Those three countries,
collectively,

those three countries' GDP
are a little over a third

of Italy's GDP, not to mention
the fact if something begins

to unfold in Italy, the
contagion effects to Spain are very significant.

All those uncertainties,
all those factors, I think work in stretching
out and delaying recovery.

So with those
thoughts-- and again, you have given us
a lot to think.

Let me try to open to
questions from our students. Willy?

Yes, our first question
is from Sayed Hassaballah. And you'll need to unmute.
And go ahead please. Hi, can you hear me? Yes, I can.

Thank you for taking the
time and for the insight. Given some of these kind
of shocking statistics

and the parallel with
the Great Depression, I'm just confused,
kind of looking at the S&P only being down 15%
since the February 2019 high.

And I was just wondering what
you kind of make of that. Thanks again.
So look, I think we are--

this is not over. So predicting equity prices has
never been one of my fortes,

to put it gently. But let me say the following. I think the reality of some of
the factors I've alluded to,

the incidence of more
defaults, the protracted nature

of the problem, I am not sure
that that is being priced

into earnings expectations. I am not sure that the full
extent of the damage on a more

sustained basis at
this moment is still

reflected in equity prices. I will say that in
any scenario, you

are going to have investors
that are in a world of zero

or negative interest
rates, whether you're looking at the US
or whether you're looking at Europe and Japan.

There's always going to
be a search for yield. So I'm not saying the
equity market is--

you know, I'm not speaking
of an L. But I am,

I think, saying
that the duration and the magnitude
of this downturn

is still not fully expected. If you look at many of
the private forecasts,

they have atrocious numbers for
the first half of this year,

pretty much across the board,
different orders of magnitude. But you turn to
the later forecast,

and you see what is more
still the expectation

of a more robust comeback. And so all I can say with
regard to the equity market

is, again, highlighting that
forecasting equity prices is

hardly my forte, but that
the seriousness is not yet

fully priced in lots of big
negatives in the first half,

but still, you turn to
the later forecasts. If you recall, as a last point,
if you recall the rocky period

post 2008-2009, you
remember we had, as I mentioned earlier, the big
initial shock of the banking

crisis, which generated a lot
of turmoil in financial markets.

And then you had
the second round associated with the European
periphery problems, which
created another round.

That's, I think, what my
sense is at the moment.

OK. Our next question
is from Alice Liu. Go ahead, Alice.

Thank you, Carmen. I was wondering if you
could elaborate more on the banking system, the
crisis impact on the banking

system and how banks
are expected to react. So that's also a
really big unknown, OK?

There is a big rift
or a big division,

a big segmentation post
Dodd-Frank regulation legacy

of the previous crisis. So after the last
crisis, we had thousands

of pages of banking
regulation, which it did

make the banks much healthier. But it also, because of
increased stress testing,

increased emphasis on
liquidity, made the banks a lot more risk averse
and much less likely

to take arbitrage
opportunities possibly

the way they would have absent
all the regulatory changes.

So you have banks
that are, you know,

initially as I said, pre-COVID,
were quite healthy for the most

part. And it's much more uneven
in the context of Europe.

In the case of emerging
markets, I would point out

that China already had a
lot of problems resulting

from having slowed from
double digit average growth to around 6% growth, and
there was a major, major--

it is the most leveraged
corporate sector,

and banks, of course, are
exposed to a huge amount

of non-performing debt. So in the US, you have a new
wave of non-performing debt.

In Europe, you have a mix of
old and new non-performing debt.

And in China, you
have also a mix of old and new
non-performing debt.

I'm highlighting this
because this really encompasses the good chunk of
the global economy, those three

groups. So what I'm getting
at is we are going

to be facing a banking sector
where a legacy, unless they are

explicitly pressured into
doing that, of a formal banking sector that is very risk
averse and not likely

to be very forthcoming on
new lending for some time. This impacts the recovery
prospect in the way

that I described
earlier of making it more likely to be a
protracted U, rather than a V.

So we have to-- somehow, we have
a banking sector where even if you didn't
have problems before,

has problems now, even
notwithstanding what are very big facilities
to support those banks

from the Federal Reserve. But I think also harking
back to an earlier remark,

I think the sense
of risk aversion

is going to be a
factor that is going to hold back renewed surge
in credit after this shock.

Let me contrast to-- and I'll conclude there. Let me contrast two very
different experiences.

In 2008-2009, part of
the very robust comeback,

after only a very brief
slowdown in China, was the surge in credit
to the private sector.

In Europe, by contrast, you look
at the Bank of International

Settlements, BIS,
credit gaps, and it took to the credit crunch
in Europe from banks,

just evergreening old loans,
but not making new ones, has lasted for years.

The US is somewhere
in between those two. So I think our
financial system is

going to bear scars
for some time, and it is not likely to
be a very robust catalyst

over the next year. I think we have time
for one quick question.
Vinod Mittal.
Vinod, you have to unmute.
Vinod? OK, let's go to Justin Troiani.

Please unmute yourself. Hi, Professor. You spoke about the Federal
Reserve and Chair Powell's

response. I'm curious what your
thoughts are about the Fed moving up the risk
curve, now supporting fallen angels and some high
yield credit, at the same time,

growing their balance sheet
from roughly 4 and 1/2 trillion to upwards of 10 trillion. So how much is too
much, and at what point

should we start to worry
about the long term effects of a risky balance
sheet and maybe the moral hazard that this has created?

Thank you. OK, so it is a
slippery slope, Justin.

It is a slippery slope. I mean, that the
Federal Reserve is now

entering new ground on moving
more and more towards the lower

quality end, and look,
I think the concern

that this crisis, and this
shares many similarities

to prior historic ones. Ultimately, the
costs are socialized.
Ultimately, we all pay for it.

I think the issue
of moral hazard

is one that we tend to worry
about more in normal times

than we do in crisis times. And we see that again and again. You know, policymakers blink
in a moment of distress,

because the contagion
fear typically

has dominated the concerns
about what it does in the future to moral hazard.

In terms of the balance
sheet, let me say this.

The ECB has been buying
non-performing assets

for many years now. The Federal Reserve actually is
coming in later to that game.

Let me say that I do not
expect, by any stretch of the imagination, that central
bank balance sheets are not

going to remain exceptionally
large by any metric

for the foreseeable future. That may be closer
to the L than the U.

What I'm getting at Justin is
that, first of all, lower asset

quality in central
bank balance sheet, it's hardly new to this crisis. As I said, the ECB has a lot
of experience on that score.

And ultimately, you
know, it will be-- the Fed, as you know,
transfers whatever

profits it has to the Treasury. Whatever losses will ultimately
be transferred to the Treasury,

and ultimately, it
will be socialized.

Sadly, we have run out of time. We could be discussing
this for longer.

This is the mother
of all crises. Thank you, Carmen, for
taking time to talk to us.

This time is truly different,
perhaps some good news. Policy makers are
acting, but this

is truly global, every person,
every market, every country. And so we need to
think how to reach

all of these affected sectors,
a call for coordination.

I think it will be
hard if we don't coordinate, and think broadly. To our students, for all
of you who have taken BGIE,

you are leaving BGIE times. And so on understanding of
the economic and financial

consequences will be
crucial in your career as this crisis unfolds and
eventually, as we get out.

Thank you very much, and I hope
you enjoy the rest of the day. Thank you, Carmen
Reinhart and Laura Alfaro
for a great session.
